The modern freakshow

Is reality TV turning into a freakshow?

Exam Hacks

Teach first scheme flawed

Is the teach first scheme helping disadvantaged children or offering a career boost to graduates

What happens in Thailand, stays in Thailand

'Sun, Sex and Suspicious Parents' misrepresents the travelling experience

Pressurise the government to change revenge porn law

Legal changes are the only real solution to revenge porn

CV blind companies demoralise students

Policies which hide attendance to well respected institutions reduce the importance of trying hard to secure a place at them

Why fancy dress is ruining York's reputation

In response to Gary Holland's argument that these fancy dress events won't cause real friction within our University, Josiah comments that it is in fact our lack of interest in their impact which is ruining York's reputation

Demonisation of fancy dress

Every child's favourite pastime suddenly becomes a political issue at university, but for no significant reason. We aren't going to start hating one another because of how we were dressed while we drank cheap cocktails.

Classroom MOTs will benefit teachers and pupils

If you look at the plans proposed by Labour objectively, rather than as a source of additional work or stress, it is clear that teachers and pupils will benefit from the proposal.

NEETS need more direction

Young people need to be able to help themselves to achieve in life, allowing school pupils to plan their lives on the dole only fails them

Breaking the body image

The prince and the pauper: a gap that cannot close

It is doubtless that Prince William's entry into Cambridge to study agricultural management is evidence of the fact that application to our most ancient institutions of learning still remains weighted in favour of the privileged. But it is also evidence of our unhealthy relationship with the monarchy.

We all have the good, the bad and the ugly in us

100 year sentences for prisoners are impractical, ignore humanity's capacity for good and the range of well researched therapies available to change behaviours

Witness the fitness, but take it all with a pinch of salt

Fitness inspiration pages present unrealistic images which we could never achieve and they in turn put people off making healthy changes to their lives

Comments on comments

By Joseph Silke

A countdown of the most controversial Comment articles of Nouse in 2013.

The best cartoons of 2013

The cartoons of Nouse 2013

New year, same old you

Backing the BBC is our British duty

Our beloved BBC needs the support of the public through TV licences, even students who squirm out of paying need to face up to it.

Separating the man from the music

Before the revelations about Lostprophets front man, Ian Watkins, came out, he was an admired musician whose band's music stole the hearts and minds of many a teenager. Now every time I hear his voice in my ears, I have to skip it. I can't listen to a word from his mouth.

No one loves a bad boy

Nothing angers the British public more than the wealthy, lazy and ungrateful. Jumping on a train therefore, whether it be gravy or actual, and taking what others have worked for, will not win you any friends in today's Britain.

Too many cooks are spoiling the broth at British universities

Chancellor Osborne's announcement last week opened up a potential 30,000 new places at universities. This will devalue our degrees and represents another stage in the failings of British universities.

Miss Represented: the media's relationship with women still has a long way to go

Creationist zoo shouldn't hide its beliefs

If you were hiding any agenda, that ship has sailed, circumnavigated the globe and returned home with two of every animal. Why not be open about it?

University needs to listen to its students and #plugthegap

As York awaits the University's announcement about bursary funding on Monday, Katie Woodard hopes it will be one that supports student opinion.

Mandela's legacy

One must remember that South Africa is dealing with the destructive legacy of Apartheid. Mandela's death is a time not only to remember his extraordinary contribution, but it is also a salutary reminder to its future leaders not to stray too far from Mandela's ideals.

Black Friday bargains bring out the worst in Britain

The savings are good and the UK's wholeheartedly adopted American celebrations before. Black Friday could well be here to stay. If it is, let's at least do it with a bit of British class.

Sun, Specs and Suspicious Parents

Admittedly, some of the geeks probably are polar opposites to the normal holiday population of Marbella, but I feel that Channel 4's judgement of what hobbies make you 'off the awkward-scale' is skewed.

It's getting hot in here

The truth is that earth is warming and we have a responsibility to curb it, especially in developing nations.

Witch hunt for Melissa Bachman needs us to take a second look

Whilst I have always been against killing animals for sport, I cannot help but feel that this frenzy surrounding the American presenter's activities has been another case of people jumping on the bandwagon.

Reclaiming the nightclubs

The modern freakshow

Is reality TV turning into a freakshow?

Exam Hacks

Is the teach first scheme helping disadvantaged children or offering a career boost to graduates
